The current administration is not going to hit upon devaluing the dollar as some kind of new strategy. It has been THE deliberate operational strategy for fleecing the public for more than a hundred years. Gold and silver were merely obstacles that needed to be pushed out of the way. They don't need to revalue gold or silver to continue doing what they have been doing for a century. In fact, as you indicate, they have no choice now. All roads lead to hyperinflation.

I'm suggesting that the government will effectively devalue the dollar. They've already devalued it from $2000 to $5000. What's two more doublings?

It reduces the cost of servicing their debt by 80% and will happen one way or another as Trump wants yield curve control (lowered interest rates) because they can't allow the US Treasury long rates to go above 5% of it starts a cascade of a debt spiral.

There is NO money in the social security "trust fund" so all the new boomer entitlements need to be covered by money printing.

Much of the government revenue comes from taxes collected from rising equity prices, hence the "Dow 50000" comment. A recession that market corrects, and results in job losses, cuts government revenues while increasing expenditures for supports and stimulus.

We are sailing into a perfect storm.

item.title: [BIZ] /XMR/ Monero General — 247 replies
item.content:encoded:
[BIZ] /XMR/ Monero General

Open thread • Replies: 247

OP

Welcome to /XMR/ Monero General, dedicated to the discussion of the world's most widely adopted privacy coin.

XMR payments are anonymous, low-fee, and fully fungible. Users can send and receive XMR globally without having to worry about tainted coins. Battle-tested privacy tech (Ring Signatures, Stealth Addresses and RingCT) ensures that critical TX data cannot be gleaned from the Monero blockchain; the TX history of all XMR users is kept hidden, with TXs being optionally transparent via the aid of a view key.

XMR ensures low TX fees by employing a dynamic block size that can "stretch" to easily accommodate sudden TX spikes.

XMR's mining algorithm, RandomX, is optimized for devices using general-purpose CPUs e.g. desktops, laptops, smartphones, tablets, keeping the barrier to entry low and ASICs out of the equation.

XMR's tail emission - 0.6 XMR per block forever - incentivizes for-profit miners to keep mining, helping boost long-term network security. This constant linear inflation trends to zero and is offset by coin loss.

XMR has proven to be the only altcoin capable of overcoming BTC's network effect by driving it out of the darknet economy BTC dominated for over 10 years. XMR is also starting to overtake BTC in clearnet commerce as well.

If you still have questions, feel free to ask. A MoneroChad will be with you shortly.

XMR Redpill: https://youtube.com/watch?v=wq6w03E2DS4

BUY XMR: https://monero.eco/exchanges/
Crypto ATMs: https://coinatmradar.com/

XMR Resources: https://monero.observer/resources/

XMR Stats: https://moneroj.net

USE XMR: https://cryptwerk.com/pay-with/xmr/

OFFICIAL WEBSITE: https://getmonero.org

MINING:
https://www.getmonero.org/get-started/mining/

WALLETS:
>Desktop
Official GUI/CLI wallet
Featherwallet
Stack Wallet

>Mobile
Cake Wallet
Monero.com
Stack Wallet
Unstoppable
Monerujo (Android)
Monfluo (Android)

>Infodumps
https://rentry.org/monero-explained
https://moneroinfodump.neocities.org

Devs, due to being part of a community and mostly unpaid, decide what they wish to implement. If it's fcmp++ they'll work on fcmp++, if it's carrot, they'll work on carrot. You can't force strangers that donate their time to do only what you want them to do especially if it's a feature you can easily avoid.
>Take a good hard look at that statement youre defending
That literally nothing will worsen with carrot? Seems like a fine statement to me.
>Since youll never post an answer to the questions,
I can't speak for anon but I already answered every question you have. If you have any other questions let me know.

61849859
>>61848827
I feel like most of the older stuff is still applicable since it's just about the basics. See picrel as an example. However I agree that the more specific guides (for example how and where to get XMR) rarely has good pictures. Do you have other bad examples so we can make a list?

>>61849231
>>cant even tell 4channers in a simple format
Five sentences isn't hard if you ask me.
>the taxman who says "gib?"
1. You already need to be deanonymized for that. The ways you can get deanonymized will stay the same. This would also be combated by using an exchange wallet. I'd probably even use an on-ramp wallet, an off-ramp wallet and a holding wallet. This way even if you were deanonymized and the IRS asks for more than what they're allowed to ask (just the income as a number, not the sources or which bank account it went to) you'd still retain your privacy.
2. This is already possible by being coerced through various means. A view key won't change that. This is proven by your next sentence. >Normies fold faster than a wet noodle.

In short: All proposed 'new' attack vectors already exist, require additional information that isn't easily obtained (they tried for years and still couldn't get it) and are easily mitigated.
Additionally, if someone for whatever reason was willing to inform the IRS of the relevant taxes by directly allowing access to view the wallet (which still is absurd and not how it works) it'd be much easier and also less risky.

If you have any other scenarios in which view keys could be exploited which are not covered already please let me know.

>>61847814

>>61856933
> No western country has a 4% inflation rate
Nigga look at the numbers, is way worse than that 4%. Look at what has happened in the last 6 years. Is only going to accelerate from here.
> World etf or S&P500
Cant you read? An etf is not the same as bonds and anon there was talking about putting 2M in bonds at 27 years old. Asuming you are going to live another 60 years is not that clear that putting all on those indexes is going to work for that long. Probably is better to diversify and buy a bit of everything.

61856947
Invest in fertilizer

61856933
>>61856745
No western country has a 4% inflation rate and a simple world ETF or the S&P500 massively outperforms inflation. 2 million invested in the S&P500 means you will have 4 million in 10 years, 8 million in 20 years, 16 million in 30 years by the time you reach normal retirement age, if you leave it all invested to let it compound. If you seriously struggle with 2 million you must be genuinely retarded and judging by your obviously very low IQ I highly doubt you have anywhere close to that much money invested.

61856888
>>61851566

Also here it's only 1% (so far) so it's not as "impressive" as the NL, but it's for all "unproductive assets", which is vague enough to eventually put everything in the basket. They already are talking about adding gold, RE, etc.. to the unrealized gains tax.

61856745
>>61856731
After 30 years at a 4% inflation rate your 2M will be 1/3 of the initial purchasing power. And your 60k will buy 20k worth, and you will be 57 years old.
And that is asuming inflation doesnt go higher (which it will go because there is no other way of getting out of the debt), and rates stay high enough where you get that 3% after taxes (which they wont for 30 years)

>>61856690
even with just 2mil you could make 60k a year AFTER tax with boring ass bonds. That´s 5k a month after tax. I understand we all have different life styles but how much money do you spend a month that requires 4mil (which would be 10k a month).

Sell everything and put it in monero and leave the country.

61856095
>>61852029
>If they pass it in UK (which could be a possibility, since they're broke and ruined) they might attempt it here.
No, it's the other way around, faggot. Your shithole country already taxes pension contributions at 15% and taxed again at 15% if it's a TTR, two things that are absolutely unthinkable in the UK. Your financial sector is so underdeveloped you don't even have anything similar to an ISA and the only way to avoid CGT is to buy bonds and hold on to them for 10 years lmao.
The UK has a million flaws but taxing wealth and investment isn't one of them. We get taxed on consumption but not even the most leftist government would think of taxing anything investment-related.
Seriously, you can stop pretending you're ahead of us when it comes to personal liberties in any way. That mask slipped years ago during COVID when the world saw what a North Korea-tier shithole your country is. And it appears it's also a shithole in terms of economic liberties.

>>61851578
>bet $10k on red
>50/50 odds, so expected value is $10k
>get taxed on unrealized $10k gains
>it's down to $7k
>win
>it's now $14k
>capital gains tax, -$4k
>back to $10k
you VILL own nothing
